displayed_text: Patient: Right. So I get twelve and twelve; I’ll take it at twelve and then I’ll take it again at twelve midnight. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: When I’m laying down and going to sleep. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And this is… Doctor: This is the sleeping pill, the Restoril. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright and these are your blood tests which you take over. Your calcium is good now so you can get… Patient: My calcium is good and I don’t have to take the big bills? Doctor: So it sounds like the big pills, you’re doing what I told you to. Doctor: Oh God.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: it as soon as possible. Okay but the chances of that happening are very small. The biggest thing is the second chemotherapy doesn’t have any danger to the nerves. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Like this one. Because this one that’s why I worry that you’re getting ten, twelve cycles now is your – are your nerves gonna start showing tingling, numbness, things like that? Patient: Yeah cuz see Doctor: Yeah. Patient: …my feet the most yeah… Doctor: Are tingling? Patient: Yeah, yeah I’ve been getting and it shrinks and so I’m saying wow. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: What the hell man. I don’t like that feeling. I don’t like… Doctor: No. Patient: It paralyzes or something. I don’t like that feeling.

Patient: I I think sh-she wants to um call for me. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Yup. Mhm. Doctor: Alright, so I will be in touch with you as soon as I have that, the result. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Nice to see you again. Patient: Same here. Doctor: Thank you. Patient: socks. Doctor: I know. Doctor: I’ll be wearing it next time.

Patient: No pain. There’s just a little; I know my right hip is there. You know I know what the sensation is. Doctor: So the radiation helped? Patient: Yes, I think so, yes. Doctor: But you still need to take the opioids. Patient: Yeah, yeah, but not as much. I’ve cut down. Doctor: So the OxyContin was two times a day and now you’re once a day. Patient: Uh sometimes none a day. Family Member: Yes. Patient: Oh OxyContin, once a day. Yes, you know I was taking the ten milligrams maybe twice a day and then once a day. And if it’s acting up a little bit in the morning well then the OxyContin, I’ll take that. But it’s not every day. As far as staying ahead of the pain then stop the pain. Doctor: You said you move your bowels. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. And uh how’s your appetite?

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Unemployed for 1 year or more: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Unemployed for 1 year or more

What is the highest grade or level of s.Less than 8 years: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Less than 8 years

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Patient: That reminds me of another question. Doctor: Um hmm. Come in. Healthcare Professional: Guess who? Doctor: Hey does he get a copy or is it just us for the…? Healthcare Professional: No, not usually but we can. Doctor: Okay, no then we’re good. Healthcare Professional: Do you want a copy? Doctor: He doesn’t need more paperwork. Healthcare Professional: Okay I need it. Doctor: Sorry, you had one more question? Patient: Shingles? Doctor: Yes. Patient: I have had a doctor tell me no, I’ve had a doctor tell me yes.

Patient: Um did you have to do radiation on them? Doctor: In some of those patients yes. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: Right and uh um. Patient: Did you come high? Doctor: Not high immediately, but uh… Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: …it continues to rise. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: And in those patients we may offer radiation therapy, radiation therapy with hormonal therapy. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: But we’ll wait and see what happens in your case.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I bet within the month you’re maybe won’t need those pads anymore. Patient: Because the other thing too is uh I coach my daughters softball team so of course get that grade down, a bucket of ball (FAM Laughs) Doctor: So even a year or two from now it’s not gonna be – you don’t have as much resistance to outflow as you used to have. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: But it should be enough that you would be dry almost all the time. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Still if you cough or pick up a heavy weight – Patient: Mm,hmm. Doctor: - still even a few years from now maybe a drop or two might come out. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Hmm, okay. (Pause) Doctor: It means that um there’s not enough prostate cancer cells to be detectable by the blood test.

Patient: Mm, hmm. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We have a one month version, we have a three month version, we have a year long version. We could start with the one-month version just to make sure things are okay. Family Member: Mm,hmm. Doctor: And I could ask my nurse to get authorization for that. So I don’t think we could just give it to you right now. Patient: Right. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: I think she has to get it improved from you insurance company and then you could come back in a week or two and get it. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And then you’ll have a consult. Family Member: Mm,hmm.

Patient: Yeah. Okay. Doctor: And this is a – when we look through all the things about what could you do that’s different in here, uh, we have this clinical study – Patient: Oh. Doctor: - and the first thing that we had to check is you had to be ARV seven expressing. Patient: That was so Doctor: So you are ARV seven positive. Patient: Ah. Doctor: That’s a bad thing. Patient: Oh. Okay. Doctor: That says, um, (laughs) Patient: I see. Doctor: Uh. So you almost have to do something that’s not chemotherapy. Sorry. Something that’s not hormone therapy. Patient: Okay. Is that the –

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: We removed it. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But it was going into it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then the question is, did it go from there elsewhere? Patient: Okay. Doctor: And that’s what we’re following. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Right now, there is no evidence that it has gone any place else in your body. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But we’ll continue to follow that.

Patient: Right. Doctor: But given that you don’t have anything else visible and all these years you haven’t had anything evolve. Patient: Right. Doctor: And this is the only area, I am thinking it’s worthwhile considering the cryo procedure. Okay? Patient: The whole thing or is this a partial? Doctor: Well no I think almost all of the prostate will need to be cryoed. So that’s why I figure Dr. C____ should come in and talk to you. Explain the details of the procedure and he’s saying that urinary leakage and everything chances are about one in four after the procedure, but that’s the risk we take and remember we talked about that that you know do we want to take that leakage risk. But given what I’m seeing is it’s that or wait until the prostate gland blocks your urinary flow which is not a good outcome at all. Right, yeah. If that wasn’t such an immediate threat, then I would have said no just sit tight, don’t do anything. Patient: Right. Doctor: But because of that threat I’m tempted to say maybe we should get it in control while we can rather than waiting until that bad outcome happens. Okay? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So that’s why I’ll have Dr. C____ come in first, explain the procedure, what it involves, what the risks are, all of that – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: - and then I’ll just touch base with you after he’s spoken to. Okay? Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So on the clinical study, we do scan him more than he would get if he was not on the clinical trial because we’re giving you more therapy than what’s usual, and they wouldn’t want us to keep giving you drugs that they’re not helping, and so they They want the actual data about scans. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So that would be a potential good thing for you. If you want more information, the study gives you more of that information. Family Member: Right. Doctor: But how I make decisions, I don’t necessarily need those scans. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: But I want to make sure on the studies everybody gets pictures of the same time points so that we can see when the cancer changes. Patient: And another question that I have. At one point we talked to acupuncturist and he said he can help through acupuncture with peeing problems. So and I was thinking we’d go on the day when we take the catheter our, but now I’m thinking maybe I should wait. And now if that is okay, see if that may be some additional help. Doctor: I don’t know. I think it’s reasonable to try. You know most acupuncturists will ask you about your current situation – Patient: Right. Doctor: - and see how well it would help. You know my worry is you know if you’re spending money on that then how does it help? You know if they are doing it and you get the catheter out is it because of my drug or because they gave you, you know acupuncture and how long you paid them?

Patient: Oh, mind blowing. Doctor: Really? Patient: Yes. Doctor: You did like safaris and stuff? I remember you told me about it. Patient: Yeah. We did safaris and the scenery. Uh, the condition of a lot of people was, was really sad. Doctor: Yeah. That’s unfortunate. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But you got to see most of the things you wanted to see? Patient: I think we did. Family Member: Yeah. We did. It was nice. (Laughter) Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: All right. Good. That’s good. Patient: Yeah.

Patient: To get going? Doctor: A week or two. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah, it will take a week or two for you to meet up with him and then we’re off and running so soon. Patient: Okay and they do the scheduling? Doctor: Yeah then it’s all them. Patient: Okay. Alright. Family Member: If he has non-cancer issues, he goes to him primary? Patient: Primary doctor, correct? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah, they’re smarter than us.

Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And for reasons that are complicated related to business and how, you know, how these things happen. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: So far, until recently, this hasn’t been in the right hands, I think, to make a drug out of it. Recently, there’s been a lot of interest and a very large company bought the rights to it, and I think they’re going to do it correctly. But it’s been a slow moving thing to get started. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And, and some of the complexity relates to, to, uh, how the drug’s supplied. Anyway, so that, that is a radioactive thing that’s coming. The radium, we could do that as just a standard treatment, not even part of a trial. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: I must say that outside of a trial, I haven’t been that excited about the radium, to be honest, in the patients I’ve treated. Family Member: Why? Doctor: Uh, it’s been kind of toxic to the bone marrow. People have kind of gotten beat up when they take it and feeling really tired. Um, and in the trials where it got approved, uh, it didn’t really have big effects on the PSA. It didn’t have big effects on shrink, you know, changing the bone. The only readout was the people who got it seemed to live long. (Sound Door closes) Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So I think, you know, we- Patient: Is that how it works when they give, give the, uh, the seeds in the prostate? Is that, is that similar to that process?
